revision.text:
{{featured article}} {{Infobox military person | name =Leslie Hubert (Les) Holden | image =LesHolden1929.jpg | image_size =260px | caption = Les Holden at Sydney's [[Sydney Airport|Mascot Aerodrome]], after locating the missing ''[[Southern Cross (aircraft)|Southern Cross]]'' in north-western Australia, 1929 |alt=Informal half portrait of man in flying suit with cap and googles emerging from the open cockpit of an aeroplane | birth_date = {{birth date|1895|3|6|df=yes}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1932|9|18|1895|3|6|df=yes}} | birth_place =East [[Adelaide]], South Australia | death_place =[[Byron Bay, New South Wales|Byron Bay]], New South Wales | nickname ="Lucky Les"; "the homing pigeon" | allegiance =Australia | branch =[[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] | serviceyears =1915–19 | rank =[[Captain (armed forces)|Captain]] | unit =[[Australian Light Horse]] (1915–16)
[[No. 2 Squadron RAAF|No. 2 Squadron AFC]] (1917–18)
[[No. 6 Squadron RAAF|No. 6 Squadron AFC]] (1918–19) | commands = | battles =World War I *[[Middle Eastern theatre of World War I|Middle East]] *[[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] *[[Battle of Cambrai (1917)|Battle of Cambrai]] *[[Spring Offensive]] | awards =[[Military Cross]]
[[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]] | laterwork = Office manager; commercial pilot }} '''Leslie Hubert''' ('''Les''') '''Holden''', [[Military Cross|MC]], [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|AFC]] (6 March 1895 – 18 September 1932) was an Australian [[flying ace|fighter ace]] of World War I and later a commercial aviator. A [[South Australia]]n, he joined the [[Australian Light Horse|Light Horse]] in May 1915, serving in Egypt and France. In December 1916, he volunteered for the [[Australian Flying Corps]] and qualified as a pilot. As a member of [[No. 2 Squadron RAAF|No. 2 Squadron]] on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]], he gained the sobriquets "Lucky Les" and "the homing pigeon" after a series of incidents that saw him limping back to base in bullet-riddled aircraft. He was awarded the [[Military Cross]], and went on to achieve five aerial victories flying [[Airco DH.5]]s and [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5]]s. Promoted to [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]], Holden finished the war as an instructor with [[No. 6 Squadron RAAF|No. 6 (Training) Squadron]] in England, where his work earned him the [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]]. After leaving the Australian Flying Corps in 1919, he became a manager at the family firm of [[Holden|Holden's Motor Body Builders]] and joined the part-time [[Royal Australian Air Force|Citizen Air Force]], before setting up as a commercial pilot and establishing his own air service. In 1929, he located [[Charles Kingsford Smith]] and [[Charles Ulm]] in the north-west Australian desert after the pair was reported missing on a flight to England in the ''[[Southern Cross (aircraft)|Southern Cross]]''. Holden began transport operations in New Guinea in 1931. He was killed the following year in a passenger plane crash in Australia. ==Family and early life== Leslie Hubert Holden was born on 6 March 1895 in [[Adelaide|East Adelaide]], South Australia, to travelling businessman Hubert William Holden and his wife Annie Maria.{{cite web|url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A090338b.htm |last=Bridge|first=Carl|title=Holden, Leslie Hubert (1895–1932)|work= [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|publisher=[[Australian National University]]|accessdate=16 May 2014}}Newton, ''Australian Air Aces'', pp. 38–39 Les was the nephew of Henry Holden, who later founded the Adelaide-based firm [[Holden|Holden's Motor Body Builders]] with his son [[Edward Holden|Edward]]. Hubert Holden landed a partnership with [[Nestlé]] in 1905, and the family moved to [[Turramurra, New South Wales|Turramurra]], New South Wales. Les completed his education at [[Sydney Church of England Grammar School]], and joined Nestlé in 1911 as a salesman. By the time [[Military history of Australia during World War I|Australia entered World War I]] in August 1914, he was an assistant manager. ==World War I== [[File:LesHolden.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Les Holden, c. 1915–18|alt=Close-up portrait of man with short dark hair]] Holden enlisted in the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] on 26 May 1915, and was posted to the [[4th Light Horse Brigade]] as a [[Private (rank)|private]]. He departed for Egypt aboard the transport A29 ''Suevic'' on 13 June.{{cite web|url=https://aif.adfa.edu.au/showPerson?pid=140588 |title=Leslie Hubert Holden|work= The AIF Project|publisher=[[University of New South Wales]]|accessdate=16 May 2014}} Serving as a driver first in the [[Middle Eastern theatre of World War I|Middle East]] and then on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]], his mechanical ability and sense of adventure led him to volunteer for the [[Australian Flying Corps]] (AFC) in December 1916. After qualifying as a pilot in England, he was commissioned a [[lieutenant]] and posted to [[No. 2 Squadron RAAF|No. 2 Squadron]]. Commanded by Major [[Oswald Watt]], No. 2 Squadron's personnel included many former Lighthorsemen, as well as mechanics from the AFC's first combat formation, the [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]]. The force trained extensively in England commencing in January 1917, before deploying to the Western Front that September.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 16–19{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_10836.asp |title=2 Squadron AFC|publisher= [[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=16 May 2014}} Holden was involved in the AFC's first day of combat in France; just after noon on 2 October, in the vicinity of [[Saint-Quentin, Aisne|Saint-Quentin]], he and his wingman engaged a German two-seater that managed to escape.Cutlack, [http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1069815--1-.PDF ''The Australian Flying Corps'', p. 178] Because its [[Airco DH.5]]s were handicapped as [[Fighter aircraft|fighters]] by engine problems and low speed, No. 2 Squadron was employed mainly in [[Close air support|ground support]] duties. During the fog-shrouded opening day of the [[Battle of Cambrai (1917)|Battle of Cambrai]] on 20 November, Holden bombed and machine-gunned a German communications trench from altitudes as low as {{convert|20|or|30|ft|m|abbr=off}}.Cutlack, [http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1069816--1-.PDF ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp. 184–185, 191] He returned to a forward airfield near [[Havrincourt|Havrincourt Wood]] with his plane "a flying wreck", in the words of the [[Official History of Australia in the War of 1914–1918|official history of Australia in the war]]. "Every part of it was shot full of holes, including petrol-tank, tail-plane, both [[longeron]]s, and part of the undercarriage, while the elevator control was shot clean away." Two days later he repeated the exercise with similar consequences for his aircraft—"clear evidence of the dangers of the work and of his own good luck", as the official history put it. This brace of close calls gained him the nicknames "Lucky Les" and "the homing pigeon".MacDougall, ''Australians at War'', pp. 148–149 He was recommended for the [[Military Cross]] on 3 December for his actions of 20 November.{{cite web|url=http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1068780--28-.PDF |title=Recommendation: Military Cross|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=16 May 2014}} The award was promulgated in the ''[[London Gazette]]'' on 4 February 1918, and the citation appeared on 5 July:{{LondonGazette|supp=yes|issue=30507|startpage=1606|date=4 February 1918 |accessdate=16 May 2014}}{{LondonGazette|supp=yes|issue=30780|startpage=7936|date=5 July 1918 |accessdate=16 May 2014}} [[File:E01883No.2SquadronAFC1918.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.32|Captains Holden (front, second from left) and [[Roy Phillipps]] (front, third from right) with officers of No. 2 Squadron and their four-legged mascots, March 1918|alt=Portrait of twenty-four men in military uniforms and flying suits, with a dog sitting in foreground and a cat on one man's lap]] {{quote|Lt. Leslie Hubert Holden, F.C. For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty. Whilst on a special mission he dropped a bomb direct on a support trench full of the enemy, causing them to scatter, and another bomb upon a strong point which was holding up our advance. He also bombed a large group of enemy infantry, and turned his machine gun on them from a height of 100 feet. He rendered very valuable service throughout the operations.}} Holden claimed his first aerial victory while No. 2 Squadron was still flying DH.5s, before it began converting to [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5]]s in December 1917.Franks, ''SE5/5a Aces of World War 1'', pp. 42–43Cutlack, [http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1069816--1-.PDF ''The Australian Flying Corps'', p. 197] On 18 February 1918, he shared in one of the unit's first two victories in the S.E.5, helping send an [[Albatros Flugzeugwerke|Albatros]] down in a spin.Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', p. 26 He claimed another three aircraft shot down over the following month, giving him a total of five victories. At least one of these took place during the [[Spring Offensive]], on 22 March, when all available Allied aircraft were thrown into battle to stem the German advance.Cutlack, [http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1069818--1-.PDF ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp. 228–230, 235] [[Royal Air Force]] policy required pilots to be rotated to home establishment for rest and instructional duties after nine to twelve months in combat.Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', p. 282 Promoted to [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]] in March 1918, Holden was posted to England in May as a flying instructor with [[No. 6 Squadron RAAF|No. 6 (Training) Squadron]] at [[Minchinhampton]].{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_10848.asp |title=6 (Training) Squadron AFC|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=16 May 2014}} His unit was part of the [[No. 1 Wing RAAF|1st Training Wing]], led by Lieutenant Colonel Watt, the former commanding officer of No. 2 Squadron.Garrisson, ''Australian Fighter Aces'', p. 12 Holden briefly took command of No. 6 Squadron from 25 July to 11 August.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/people_1076796.asp |title=Captain Leslie Hubert Holden|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=16 May 2014}} He was awarded the [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]], promulgated on 3 June 1919, for his skill as an instructor.{{LondonGazette|supp=yes|issue=31378|startpage=7032|endpage=7033|date=3 June 1919 |accessdate=16 May 2014}} ==Post-war career and legacy== [[File:Vn3930951HoldenCanberraMoth.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.38|Holden in the cockpit of ''Canberra'', his DH.61 Giant Moth, with passengers at Mascot Aerodrome, c. 1930|alt=Two women standing in front of large biplane with man in flying gear seated in open cockpit]] No. 6 Squadron was disbanded in March 1919. Along with many other Australian Flying Corps personnel including Colonel Watt, Major [[Elwyn Roy King|Roy King]], and Captain [[Garnet Malley]], Holden departed for Australia on 6 May aboard the troopship ''Kaisar-i-Hind'', disembarking in Sydney on 19 June.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15850643 |title=Airmen return|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=20 June 1919 |accessdate=18 July 2014 |page=9 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} He was discharged from the AFC on 18 August 1919.{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=5284259|author=[[Australian Military Forces]]|title=Holden, Arthur Hubert|date=1914–20|page=36|accessdate=16 May 2014}} After taking part in the Commonwealth Government's Peace Loan flights, he joined Holden's Motor Body Builders as its [[Sydney]] manager. In May 1921, he served with Malley and other veteran pilots as a pall-bearer at Watt's funeral in [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]].{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15945306|title=The late Col. Watt: Tributes in church and cemetery|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|location=Sydney |date=24 May 1921|page=8|accessdate=12 February 2010|publisher=National Library of Australia}} Holden married Kathleen Packman at St Mark's Anglican Church in [[Darling Point, New South Wales|Darling Point]] on 3 June 1924; the couple had three daughters. On 19 June 1925, the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) established the Citizen Air Force as a part-time active reserve, and Holden became one of its first recruits.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 226–226Gillison, [http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070524--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 712–713] Ranked [[flight lieutenant]], he served as a pilot with [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]], which operated [[Airco DH.9]]s and S.E.5s. Formed at [[RAAF Williams|RAAF Point Cook]], Victoria, it transferred to the newly opened [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Richmond]], New South Wales, during 29–30 June; Holden and Malley touched down at Richmond with the first two S.E.5s on the 30th.Coulthard-Clark, ''Third Brother'', pp. 134–135Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 123 Still hankering after a full-time career in flying, Holden enlisted the help of friends to purchase a [[De Havilland Giant Moth|de Havilland DH.61 Giant Moth]] in 1928. He named it ''Canberra'', and used it to start a charter operation out of [[Sydney Airport|Mascot Aerodrome]] in Sydney. Holden became a national celebrity in April 1929 when he successfully undertook an aerial search of the north-western Australian wilderness to locate [[Charles Kingsford Smith]] and [[Charles Ulm]], after the pair had gone missing on a flight from Sydney to England in the ''[[Southern Cross (aircraft)|Southern Cross]]''. Two other searchers, Keith Anderson and Bob Hitchcock, were lost in their aircraft, the ''Kookaburra''. The media of the day turned on Smith and Ulm, accusing them of a publicity stunt, and the Sydney Citizens' Relief Committee, which had commissioned Holden to undertake the rescue operation, withheld payment of his expenses.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 297–303 He nevertheless continued flying commercially, and is credited with making—in September 1931—possibly the first flight from Sydney to New Guinea, where he started an air freight service. Returning to Sydney the following year, he established Holden's Air Transport Services. He also acquired two more aircraft for his New Guinea operations, a [[Waco Aircraft Company|Waco]] and a Moth, to supplement the ''Canberra''.Idriess, ''Gold-Dust and Ashes'', p. 169 {{Quote box |width=26% |align=right |quote=To think that Holden, who had never had a mishap when flying over these dangerous mountains, should be killed when on holiday in Australia, flying to a fishing expedition. It seemed sad to me that I should be taking hospitality in his house, a house like an eagle's eyrie, with a lookout all round such as a flying man would wish for—and his boy continuing to chant his epitaph, "He was a good ''masta''." |source=Sarah Chinnery on staying at Holden's house in [[Salamaua]], New Guinea, in February 1933.Fortune, ''Malaguna Road'', pp. 70, 77 }} On 18 September 1932, Holden was travelling as a passenger aboard a [[List of defunct airlines of Oceania|New England Airways]] [[De Havilland Puss Moth|DH.80 Puss Moth]] from Sydney to [[Brisbane]] when it crashed at [[Byron Bay, New South Wales|Byron Bay]] in northern New South Wales, killing him instantly. The other occupants, pilot Ralph Virtue and the joint owner of the ''Canberra'', Holden's schoolfriend Dr George Hamilton, also perished. Investigations determined that the Puss Moth, VH-UPM, had gone down as a result of wing failure caused by [[aileron]] flutter.{{cite report | title = Aircraft Accident Investigation at ARL: The First 50 Years | url = http://handle.dtic.mil/100.2/ADA267086 | last = Kepert | first = J.L. | date = March 1993 | publisher = [[Defence Science and Technology Organisation]] |accessdate=16 May 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17115390?|title=Memorial Windows: Shore Grammar School |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|location=Sydney|page=6|date=29 December 1934 |accessdate=16 May 2014|publisher=National Library of Australia}} A crowded memorial service for Holden and Hamilton took place at Sydney Church of England Grammar School on 20 September; they were cremated that afternoon at [[Rookwood Cemetery]], where eighteen aircraft piloted by friends and associates of the pair overflew the chapel.{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/2305707?searchTerm=les+Holden+funeral|title=Air Crash Victims: Memorial Service|newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]]|location=Canberra|page=2|date=21 September 1932 |accessdate=16 May 2014|publisher=National Library of Australia}} Holden was survived by his wife and children. His father Hubert carried on operating Holden's Air Transport Services, floating it as a public corporation and serving as chairman.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Go4TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OZYDAAAAIBAJ&dq=les-holden&pg=5561%2C1118092|title=The Late Mr. Hubert William Holden |newspaper=The Sydney Mail|location=Sydney| page=57|date=16 January 1935 |accessdate=16 May 2014|publisher=National Library of Australia}} Les Holden, George Hamilton, and one of their schoolmates who had also recently died, Henry Braddon, were commemorated with a memorial stained-glass window at the Sydney Church of England Grammar School chapel in 1934. Holden was also honoured by Holden Street, built in the Sydney suburb of [[Maroubra, New South Wales|Maroubra]] in 1943.{{cite web| url=http://www.randwick.nsw.gov.au/About_Randwick/Heritage/History_of_the_Randwick_area/Street_park_and_place_names/Street_names_G_to_L/index.aspx|title=Street names G to L|publisher=[[City of Randwick|Randwick City Council]]|accessdate=16 May 2014}} ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Coulthard-Clark| first=Chris|year=1991| title=The Third Brother: The Royal Australian Air Force 1921–39| location=North Sydney| publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]]|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/437/The-Third-Brother-The-Royal-Australian-Air-Force-1921-39.aspx|isbn=0-04-442307-1}} * {{cite book|last=Cutlack | first=F.M.| origyear=1923|year=1941| title=The Official History of Australia in the War of 1914–1918 (11th edition): Volume VIII – The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres of War, 1914–1918 | location=Sydney| publisher=[[Angus & Robertson]]|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1069925/|oclc=220900299}} * {{cite book|last=Franks|first=Norman|title=SE5/5a Aces of World War 1 |year=2007|publisher=[[Osprey Publishing|Osprey]]|location=Oxford|isbn=1-84603-180-X}} * {{cite book|last=Garrisson|first=A.D.|title=Australian Fighter Aces 1914–1953|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/220/Australian-Fighter-Aces-1914–1953.aspx|publisher=Air Power Studies Centre|location=Fairbairn, Australian Capital Territory|year=1999|isbn=0-642-26540-2}} * {{cite book|last=Gillison | first=Douglas |year=1962| title=Australia in the War of 1939–1945: Series Three (Air) Volume I – Royal Australian Air Force 1939–1942 | location=Canberra| publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]| url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1070209/|oclc=2000369}} * {{cite book|last=Fortune|first=Kate (ed.)|title=Malaguna Road: The Papua and New Guinea Diaries of Sarah Chinnery |year=1998|publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]|location=Canberra|isbn=0-642-10687-8}} * {{cite book|last= Idriess | first=Ion Llewellyn |year=1964| title=Gold-Dust and Ashes: The Romantic Story of the New Guinea Goldfields | location=Sydney| publisher=Angus & Robertson| oclc=12336859}} * {{cite book|last=MacDougall| first=A.K.|year=2007| origyear=1991|title=Australians at War: A Pictorial History| location= Rowville, Victoria| publisher=Five Mile Press |isbn=978-1-74178-957-7}} * {{cite book|last=Molkentin| first=Michael|year=2010| title=Fire in the Sky: The Australian Flying Corps in the First World War| location= Crows Nest, New South Wales| publisher=Allen & Unwin|isbn=1-74237-072-1}} * {{cite book|last=Newton| first=Dennis|year=1996| title=Australian Air Aces| location=Fyshwyck, Australian Capital Territory| publisher=Aerospace Publications|isbn=1-875671-25-0}} * {{cite book|last=Stephens| first=Alan|origyear=2001|year=2006| title=The Royal Australian Air Force: A History|location=London| publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=0-19-555541-4}} * {{cite book|last=Wilson| first=David|year=2005| title=The Brotherhood of Airmen| location=Crows Nest, New South Wales| publisher=Allen & Unwin |isbn=1-74114-333-0}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|last= Sinclair | first=James Patrick |year=1978| title=Wings of Gold: How the Aeroplane Developed New Guinea| location=Sydney | publisher=Pacific Publications| isbn=978-0-85807-033-2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holden, Les}}
